transcripts.text: This is the end of the video.  We'll get started in 10 to 15 minutes.  Hi, I'm Scott Ott with Bill Whittle now.  And Bill, interesting story coming to us from the New York Post that NASA has discovered the possibility of a parallel universe where time runs backwards.  Now, it's kind of complicated how they discovered this, but essentially they're floating this radio signal detector above the Antarctic.  And I'll give you the mystical paragraph that the post has.  The experts use a giant balloon to carry NASA's Antarctic Impulsive Transient Antenna, they dub ANITA, high above the Antarctic where the frigid dry air provides a perfect environment with little to no radio noise to distort the findings.  Apparently the Earth is constantly being bombarded by high energy particles that are constantly arriving from outer space.  Some of the low energy subatomic neutrinos actually pass right through the Earth because they have zero mass.  However, high energy objects are stopped by the planet's mass.  But the problem is almost, therefore all the heavy particles, all the high energy particles are coming down from space, except for something they discovered, which are something they call TAU, TAU neutrinos, which come up out of the earth.  Now the finding implies that these particles are actually traveling backward in time, suggesting evidence of a parallel universe.  And believe it or not, Bill, that's what they said is the simplest explanation.
Damn you, Tau neutrinos.  Get off of my lawn.  Get off of my vast Antarctic lawn.
Now, I bring this up to you because I know you're a big science fiction fan and an amateur, and by that I mean lover of science and all things space.  How does this strike you at first hearing?

I think it's confirmation, or let me rephrase that.  It's another piece of evidence in a belief that I think has been... seriously backed by mathematics and advanced physics.  And it's not a science fiction idea.  Parenthetically, I started teaching astronomy in the Miami Planetarium when I was 14, I think, so I've been in this field for a while now.  When you look at cosmology, you look at advanced physics, you look at physics on the quantum level, right at the outer boundaries of things that are as far away from our day-to-day existence as you can get, things start to fray a little bit.  And I think this is really important to have this understood in the beginning.  So I'm just gonna get this said because some of the stuff that we're gonna talk about briefly is very, very difficult to understand.  There is a limit to what we can understand as human beings, what we can really understand.  What we can hypothesize is virtually unlimited.  There's some pretty compelling evidence that we live in an 11-dimensional universe, and that all of it is tied up in these strings, in this cosmic string theory and all the rest.  And I don't mean this to sound anti-human and to the extreme contrary.  I'm exceedingly proud of the human race.  I'm exceedingly proud to be a member of them.  And I'm exceedingly proud that a bunch of upright chimps basically can figure out so much about the way the universe is built.  Nevertheless, and this is the important point, There comes a limit, and I call it the horsepower limit.  There is a limit to how much our brains are able to process.  that is determined just by the number of neurons, and that's it.  In other words, I could take a hamster and train it to fly an instrument approach as many times as I could take lifetimes of generations of hamsters, or chimps for that matter, chimps a better example.  I could take a chimpanzee into an airplane and try to train it how to fly an instrument approach And it doesn't matter how long I try, and it doesn't matter how good I am as an instructor, the chimp doesn't have the mental horsepower to be able to do that particular task.  And likewise, there are elements of the things that we're able to imagine and model that seem so contradictory and so impossible that I have described it as we have run up against the horsepower limit of our own brains to understand it.  Eternity is one of those things.  Infinity is something else.  We both know what eternity and infinity means, but we can't conceive of them.  We always think that infinity means, well, it's huge.  Yes, it's huge, all right.  Well, what's on the other end of the huge?  Nothing, there is no other end.  Well, what do you mean?  Well, there's nothing on the other end.  It just keeps going forever, but it's gotta stop someplace.  When you talk about the expanding universe, stay with me, folks.  You talk about the universe expanding from the Big Bang, and our brains are determined to think, okay, so the whole universe is inside this bubble, right?  Yes, absolutely, you've got it.  What's on the other side of the bubble?  Nothing.  What, you mean like empty space?  No, no, nothing.  There's nothing on the other side of the bubble.  Vacuum?  No, no, you don't understand.  There is nothing on the other side of the bubble.  There's nothing.  There is no existence there.  And this is where the horsepower restrictions come in and allow us to talk about things in forms of models, but not really be able to comprehend them in a real way.  All is to say that of all the mysteries in physics, as you get closer to the boundaries in quantum and in super gravity and all the rest of it, the one thing that seems to be a consistent problem, a problem, is time.  Time continually gets in the way of a clear understanding of things.  And we have known for quite a long time that there's a particle called a positron.  It's a positively charged electron.  You can think of it as a positively charged electron, or you can think of it as an electron that's moving backwards in time.  And this seems impossible to us because we're running into our horsepower limitations.  But to give you a conclusion of what I personally think, based on a lot of scientific evidence, I think that you make a very strong case that the universe is constructed, and this is, again, the best way I can explain this to fellow chimps, It is a construct, it's physically built, and time is simply a passage through this construct.  Now, we are limited in our perception to being able to see only in one direction, but it's all equally real.  So if I were to hand you an old LP, or a cassette tape for that matter, or whatever else these crazy nutty kids are using, an LP is a good example.  If I hand you a Frank Sinatra record, and I ask you what part of that record is more real, you would say that's an absurd statement.  You would question my sanity.  But if I played the record, if I put the needle on the groove and played the record, you would be hearing Frank Sinatra.  You'd know that there's lyrics coming up and you know that there's lyrics behind, but you can't experience those.  Those are outside the realms of our ability.  If you've never heard the album before, you have no idea what's coming.  That record is constructed, but the consciousness of ours is limited to what the groove is on at that particular time.  So all of that to simply say that the entire idea of something running backwards in time is not necessarily proof of another universe so much as it's proof of the universe that exists and access to moving through that universe in directions that we don't have access to move in.

It's interesting, as you were speaking, Bill, I thought of the scripture that says, with the Lord, a day is as a thousand years and a thousand years is as a day.  Let's just put a button on this for this episode by talking about the implications. What, if any, implications are there for us humanoid chimps?  And in addition, I thought one of the most interesting questions that rose in this article was the possibility that if there are beings in the parallel universe, they would perceive that we are running backward in time.  Of course.

Of course, and there's no objective way to know.  There's a particularly fascinating literary example of this, and that's Merlin.  In the King Arthur legends, Merlin was living life backwards.  He was born old and getting younger as the story went on.  That's why he could see the future.  The future for Arthur was the past for Merlin.  And since it's such an interesting topic, to say that these particles are coming out of the Earth is not to me to say that there's an alternate universe.  It's just that something is moving backwards along the same groove of this record.  There could be infinite number of alternate universes.  But in any event, what this does for me and what I would hope it would do for many people is to make you realize that when people make statements with certainty about things of this nature, there's a great deal of arrogance involved.  And I ought to know because I was certainly one of those people.  I thought, what's so hard to understand? On one hand, it makes me enormously humble to realize how much of reality is so far complex beyond our ability to perceive it that any certainty about the situation that we live in is a certainty about such an infinitesimally small slice of the complexity of what's really out there.
